> Maintain an academic tone, use proper scientific terminology, and cite relevant references (APA-style placeholders like [Author, Year]).

this is my material method "Materials and Methods
Soil Properties

Soil samples were collected from the top layer (2–15 cm) of agricultural land in Bojnourd, North Khorasan Province, Iran (37°38′29″ N, 57°01′52″ E). The soil texture was classified as silty clay loam (20% sand, 45% silt, 35% clay). Soil characteristics were as follows: CaCO₃ content of 22.5% determined by the method of Loeppert and Suarez (1996) [7]; pH of 7.7 (in H₂O); electrical conductivity (EC) of 0.7 dS m⁻¹ measured in saturated soil paste according to Corwin and Rhoades (1982) [8]; cation exchange capacity (CEC) of 16.8 cmol_c kg⁻¹; and organic carbon content of 0.39% as determined by the Walkley–Black method (Mylavarapu et al., 2014; Nelson & Sommers, 1996) [9,10]. Total Kjeldahl nitrogen (TKN) was 0.036% (Bremner & Mulvaney, 1982) [11]. Available phosphorus (Olsen-P) and potassium were 4.8 and 300 mg kg⁻¹, respectively. DTPA-extractable micronutrients (mg kg⁻¹) were: Fe (3.7), Zn (0.22), Mn (7.1), Cd (0.03), and Pb (25). After air-drying and sieving (<2 mm), soil was homogenized and amended with urea (80 mg N kg⁻¹), triple superphosphate (136.36 mg P₂O₅ kg⁻¹), and KNO₃ (42.16 mg K₂O kg⁻¹) prior to use.
Experimental Design

A pot experiment was established at Talae Sefid Atrak Cotton Cleaning Company using plastic pots (20 cm bottom diameter, 25 cm height), each filled with ~8 kg of contaminated soil. Cotton (Gossypium hirsutum L. cv. LIDER) seeds were procured from Golden West Co. Three seedlings were planted per pot. The experiment followed a completely randomized design (CRD) with three replications per treatment.
Soil Contamination and Treatment Application

Soil was spiked with CdCl₂ and Pb(NO₃)₂ to reach contamination levels of 100 mg Cd kg⁻¹ and 500 mg Pb kg⁻¹. Natural, unspiked soil served as control, with background Cd and Pb levels of 0.53 and 25 mg kg⁻¹, respectively. Five foliar treatments were applied: (1) sodium nitroprusside (SNP) at 100 µM weekly (Per et al., 2017) [S1], (2) sodium hydrosulfide (NaHS) at 100 µM biweekly (Bali et al., 2019) [S2], (3) glutathione (GSH) at 2 mM biweekly (Cao et al., 2013) [S3], (4) cysteine at 2 mM biweekly (Bashri & Prasad, 2016) [S4], and (5) distilled water as foliar control. Spray applications began 1–2 weeks after seedling establishment, depending on the treatment. Moisture was maintained at 70% water-holding capacity. Plants were harvested after 128 days, separated into organs, and dried at 65°C to constant weight.
Mineral Analysis of Plant Tissues

Dried leaf and root tissues (0.5 g) were digested using HNO₃–HClO₄ acid mixture (Hseu, 2004; Horwitz, 2000) [12,13]. Mineral concentrations (Cd, Pb, Fe, Mn, Cu, Zn) were measured using ICP-OES (Spectro Arcos, Germany), following calibration with certified standards and inclusion of blanks (Gheshlaghi et al., 2019) [14].
Antioxidant Enzyme Assays

Fresh leaf samples (0.5 g) were homogenized in ice-cold extraction buffer (50 mM phosphate buffer, 1 mM EDTA, 1% PVP, pH 7.8) and centrifuged (20 min, 4°C, 15,000×g).

    SOD Activity was measured via inhibition of NBT photoreduction at 560 nm (Beauchamp & Fridovich, 1971) [15].

    CAT Activity was assessed by monitoring H₂O₂ decomposition at 240 nm (Aebi, 1984) [16].

    APX Activity was determined using ascorbate oxidation at 290 nm (Nakano & Asada, 1981) [17].

Protein content was quantified by the Bradford assay (Bradford, 1976) [18].
Glutathione Quantification

Reduced and oxidized GSH (GSH, GSSG) were measured in leaves and roots using 2% metaphosphoric acid and the method of Luwe et al. (1993), as described by Carlberg & Mannervik (1985) and Gheshlaghi et al. (2019) [14,19,20].
Hormone and Ascorbate Analysis

    Ascorbate (Asc) was determined using the α,α-dipyridyl method (Tanaka et al., 1980; Gheshlaghi et al., 2019) [14,21].

    Gibberellic Acid (GA) was analyzed via methanol extraction, ethyl acetate partitioning, and spectrophotometry at 254 nm (Berríos et al., 2004) [22].

    Abscisic Acid (ABA) was extracted and quantified using HPLC with a C18 column and acetonitrile-methanol mobile phase (Kelen et al., 2004) [23].

RNA Extraction, cDNA Synthesis, and qRT-PCR

Total RNA was extracted from fresh leaves using TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen, USA), and cDNA synthesis was performed using the Vazyme HiScript II Q RT SuperMix Kit. Primers (Table S2) were designed based on NCBI sequences. Gene expression of Fe-SOD, CAT, GR, and APX was analyzed using ABI 7500 Fast Real-Time PCR, with ef1 as the reference gene. The 2^−ΔΔCt method was used for relative quantification.
Hydrogen Sulfide (H₂S) Quantification

H₂S levels in plant tissues were determined by the methylene blue method, measuring absorbance at 670 nm and calculating concentration using the extinction coefficient (Li, 2015) [Li].
Phytoremediation Efficiency Evaluation

Cadmium accumulation was assessed via:

    BCF (bioconcentration factor): Cd concentration in root or shoot / Cd concentration in soil,

    TF (translocation factor): Cd concentration in shoot / Cd in root,

    Phytoextraction efficiency: [(shoot Cd + root Cd uptake)/total soil Cd] × 100 (Jan et al., 2021; Yang et al., 2021) [24,25].

Data Analysis

Data analysis was conducted using Microsoft Excel 2016, SPSS v13.0, and OriginPro 2019b. One-way ANOVA followed by Duncan’s multiple range test (p < 0.05) was used to identify statistically significant differences among treatments."please cheak all ref in text that was correct and modify text as scientific sound for article journal with provide citation in text apa

This study proposes to conduct a thorough review of the Knowledge Management System in the Finance and Administration Section of a state hospital in Malta. It intends to critically analyse and identify gaps within the existing KMS framework and propose enhancements through the application of theoretical models while addressing the unique cultural and operational dynamics of the organization.
Knowledge is regarded as an intellectual asset that is not depleted when used, not lost when shared, yet a significant amount of it is often lost by organisations (Dalkir, 2023). Knowledge management (KM) is a systematic approach to acquire, structure, manage and spread knowledge within an organization to enable such to identify and reuse the best and most efficient work practices whilst reduce costly rework from project to project (Nonaka, Toyama, & Konno, 2000; Pasternack & Viscio, 1998; Pfeffer & Sutton, 1999; Ruggles & Holtshouse, 1999).
This section outlines the background (section 1.1) and context (section 1.3) of the research, and its purposes (section 1.4). Section 1.5 describes the significance and scope of this research and provides definitions of terms used. Finally, section 1.7 includes an outline of the remaining sections of the assignment.

Il s'agit d'une analyse largement utilisée en chimie des substances naturelles et en pharmacognosie. . L’intensité de cette coloration bleue, mesurée par spectrophotométrie à environ 760–765 nm, est proportionnelle à la concentration en composés phénoliques dans l’échantillon (Boizot & Charpentier, 2006). Les résultats sont généralement exprimés en équivalents d’acide gallique (EAG) par gramme de matière sèche.

Les composés phénoliques, ou polyphénols, représentent une large classe de métabolites secondaires présents dans le règne végétal. Ils comprennent des molécules simples, comme l’acide salicylique, jusqu’à des structures plus complexes, notamment les tanins et les flavonoïdes liés à des glucosides. Ces composés jouent un rôle fondamental dans la défense des plantes contre les agents pathogènes et les insectes phytophages. Ils sont reconnus pour leurs propriétés antioxydantes, anti-inflammatoires, antiseptiques et antivirales. Parmi eux, le resvératrol, un stilbène isolé notamment du raisin, est l’un des plus étudiés pour ses puissants effets antioxydants (Igor, 2002).
Les flavonoïdes représentent l’un des groupes de polyphénols les plus abondants dans le règne végétal et dans notre alimentation (Dai & Mumper, 2010)

Composés de plus de 6 000 molécules naturelles, ils sont largement répandus dans les plantes vasculaires, où ils jouent un rôle crucial dans la coloration des fleurs, des fruits et parfois des feuilles, grâce à des pigments tels que les flavonols jaunes, les anthocyanosides rouges ou violets (Bruneton, 1999)

Leur structure chimique repose sur un squelette C6-C3-C6, formé de deux noyaux aromatiques (A et B) reliés par une chaîne de trois atomes de carbone formant un hétérocycle oxygéné (noyau C) (Boubekri, 2014 ; De Rijke et al., 2006).

En plus de leur rôle pigmentaire, les flavonoïdes présentent de nombreuses vertus thérapeutiques : propriétés antioxydantes, anti-inflammatoires, antivirales, vasoprotectrices et hépatoprotectrices. Ils sont couramment retrouvés dans les plantes médicinales, le thé, le vin rouge, les agrumes, ou encore le sarrasin (Ghedira, 2005 ; Igor, 2002). Certains, comme la rutine et l’hespéridine, renforcent les capillaires sanguins et préviennent l’infiltration des fluides dans les tissus environnants.

En plus de leur rôle pigmentaire, les flavonoïdes présentent de nombreuses vertus thérapeutiques : propriétés antioxydantes, anti-inflammatoires, antivirales, vasoprotectrices et hépatoprotectrices. Ils sont couramment retrouvés dans les plantes médicinales, le thé, le vin rouge, les agrumes, ou encore le sarrasin (Ghedira, 2005 ; Igor, 2002).

La méthode de référence pour la détermination des flavonoïdes totaux est la méthode colorimétrique au trichlorure d’aluminium (AlCl₃), initialement développée par Lamaison et Carnet (1991), puis améliorée par Bahorun et al. (1996). Elle repose sur la formation d’un complexe stable et coloré entre les ions Al³⁺ et les flavonoïdes présents dans l’extrait végétal, en milieu acide. Ce complexe développe une coloration jaune dont l’intensité d’absorption maximale est mesurée à 409 nm (Boulekbache, 2005).

Les tanins sont des composés phénoliques secondaires abondamment présents dans le règne végétal, principalement localisés dans les parois cellulaires ou stockés dans les vacuoles des organes tels que les tiges, l’écorce, les feuilles, les fleurs ou les graines, particulièrement chez les dicotylédones. Ils sont historiquement connus pour leur capacité à fixer les protéines, ce qui leur a valu une utilisation traditionnelle dans le tannage des peaux animales. Ces substances hydrosolubles, de masse moléculaire comprise entre 500 et 3000 Da, ont la capacité de précipiter les alcaloïdes, la gélatine et diverses protéines, leur conférant ainsi des propriétés astringentes (Bruneton, 1999 ; Hopkins, 2003).
La quantification des tanins condensés repose sur la méthode colorimétrique à la vanilline-HCl, telle que décrite par Sun et al. (1998).

Les acides phénoliques constituent la deuxième classe la plus abondante de polyphénols après les flavonoïdes (Amawi et al., 2017). Ils sont largement présents dans les végétaux et reconnus pour leurs puissantes propriétés antioxydantes. On les retrouve principalement dans les graines, la peau des fruits, les légumes à feuilles et d’autres parties des plantes utilisées dans l’alimentation (Prabhu et al., 2021). Sur le plan chimique, les acides phénoliques sont définis comme des composés organiques possédant au moins un groupe carboxylique et un groupe hydroxyle porté par un noyau aromatique (Bruneton, 1999). En phytochimie, cette appellation est souvent réservée aux dérivés des acides benzoïques (acides hydroxybenzoïques) et des acides cinnamiques (acides hydroxycinnamiques) (Boubekri, 2014). Ces composés existent sous forme libre ou conjuguée, liés à des sucres ou estérifiés à d'autres acides. Ils jouent un rôle important dans les mécanismes de défense des plantes et sont impliqués dans diverses interactions biologiques, notamment avec des bactéries (Bohn-Courseau et al., 2009). De plus, ils constituent des précurseurs de nombreuses autres familles de métabolites secondaires tels que les coumarines, les lignines, les tanins, les flavonoïdes et les isoflavonoïdes (Hopkins, 2003).

La détermination des acides phénoliques totaux repose sur la méthode colorimétrique d’Arnow. Cette technique utilise un couple de réactifs (molybdate de sodium et nitrite de sodium) qui réagit spécifiquement avec les fonctions phénoliques des acides hydroxycinnamiques présents dans l’échantillon, formant un complexe coloré mesurable par spectrophotométrie. L’intensité de la coloration produite est proportionnelle à la concentration des acides phénoliques, et son absorption maximale est détectée à 490 nm. Une courbe d’étalonnage est établie à l’aide de l’acide caféique comme composé de référence.

Title: A Regional Soil Classification Framework for Targeted Site-Specific Health Management in Missouri.

Abstract: Soil health corroborates sustainable agriculture, ecosystem resilience, and water quality. However, variability in soil properties across landscapes poses challenges for generalized management recommendations. This study presents Missouri’s Soil Health Blueprint, a regional soil classification framework for site-specific soil health management strategies. Leveraging high-resolution SSURGO data, we apply multivariate analysis—including principal component analysis and unsupervised clustering—to delineate soil classes that capture textures, hydraulic properties, chemical fertility, and biological indicators unique to Missouri’s physiographic regions. Clusters were validated using silhouette scores, spatial coherence checks, and comparisons to existing taxonomic units. The resulting classification map identifies eight distinct soil health management zones, each characterized by a signature combination of clay content, organic matter, pH, available water capacity, and salinity indicators. We demonstrate how growers, conservation planners, and agronomists can use these zones to tailor amendment rates, crop rotations, and conservation practices to local soil constraints. This framework advances precision soil health by bridging data-driven classification with actionable, site-targeted recommendations, ultimately fostering more efficient resource use and improved environmental outcomes across Missouri’s diverse agricultural landscapes.
Introduction:
Context & Motivation

Soil health is a critical determinant of crop productivity, carbon sequestration, and watershed integrity. In Missouri—where agriculture contributes over $10 billion annually—heterogeneous soil conditions across glaciated plains, loess hills, and alluvial valleys demand management approaches that respond to local soil attributes rather than broad county-level prescriptions. Conventional classification systems often lack the resolution or translational pathway to guide tailored soil-building interventions, leading to suboptimal fertilizer use, uneven yields, and environmental risks.
Current State of the Art

Recent advances in soil data collection (e.g., SSURGO’s detailed spatial layers) and machine learning have enabled automated classification workflows. Studies have demonstrated the utility of clustering algorithms and principal component analysis to group soils by texture, hydrology, and chemistry. Yet most applications remain academic proofs of concept or focus on small watersheds, without translating clusters into management zones or validating against agronomic outcomes.
Research Gap & Problem Statement

Despite rich spatial datasets, Missouri lacks a unified, data-driven soil classification that directly informs on-farm management. Existing taxonomic units do not readily translate into variable-rate nutrient recommendations or conservation practice design. There is a critical need for a framework that both captures the multidimensional nature of soil health and delivers practical, site-specific guidance.
Objectives & Contributions
This study addresses that gap by:
1.	Developing an unsupervised classification pipeline that integrates physical, chemical, and biological soil indicators from SSURGO.
2.	Validating clusters through statistical metrics and spatial coherence.
3.	Translating soil classes into ----------- management zones, each with tailored recommendations for amendments, rotations, and conservation practices.
4.	Providing an open-access map and decision support guidelines for stakeholders across Missouri.
Paper Organization

The remainder of this paper is structured as follows. Section 2 reviews relevant soil health indicators and clustering methodologies. Section 3 details our data processing and analytical workflow. Section 4 presents the classification results and management zone delineation. Section 5 discusses practical implications, limitations, and future enhancements. Finally, Section 6 concludes with recommendations for implementation and research directions.

The authors identify a gap in soil health research: diagnostics and management strategies are rarely tailored to the inherent variability of soils. Leveraging the SSURGO database across California’s Central and Coastal Valleys (5.6 M ha), they performed K‑means clustering on ten surface‑soil properties (0–30 cm) plus depth to root‑restrictive horizons. Metrics and validation tests justified a seven‑region conceptual model that distinguishes soils without performance limitations from those limited by (a) root restrictive horizons, (b) salinity/alkalinity, and (c) shrink–swell behavior; further subdividing by texture and/or organic matter into seven coherent regions. This framework offers a testable, place‑based approach for soil health diagnosis and management.

Soil health is the capacity of soil to function as a living ecosystem, supporting plant, animal, and human needs. Research has focused on validating practices (cover crops, reduced tillage, compost) but often overlooks inherent soil variability.

Challenge: Separating effects of management from inherent soil‑forming factors. Prior studies found physiographic region often dominates over management in explaining soil health metrics.

Gap: No region‑wide soil classification tailored to soil health diagnostics in Western U.S.

Objective: Use unsupervised classification of SSURGO‑derived surface properties and root‑restrictive horizons to define soil “health regions” in California’s Central and Coastal Valleys, hypothesizing systematic variability (a) exists at regional scale and (b) differs meaningfully from USDA‑NRCS Soil Taxonomy.

Research Strategy (≈ 3 000 words)

1. Motivation

Biomedical discovery today remains throttled by the long turnaround time between a clinician’s research question and delivery of an analysable EHR extract.  Even at data‑rich institutions like the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB), investigators wait weeks for database developers to interpret requests, craft SQL, check PHI compliance, and generate CSV files that must then be merged with external resources such as MIMIC‑III.  The friction slows hypothesis iteration and delays translation of discoveries to the bedside.

Large‑language‑model (LLM) breakthroughs—especially open‑weight models that can run safely behind a firewall—offer a path to disrupt this cycle.  Yet merely dropping an LLM into a clinical stack is insufficient: EHR schemas such as OMOP are highly normalised, governed by strict privacy rules, and constantly evolving.  Without specialised agentic orchestration, an LLM will produce fragile queries, omit provenance, and risk PHI leakage.  AgenticAI addresses these challenges head‑on by combining (i) on‑premise, high‑capacity LLM serving; (ii) an ensemble of purpose‑built LangChain agents; and (iii) a first‑class privacy layer grounded in differential privacy, federated execution, and Named‑Entity‑Recognition (NER) redaction.

2. Gaps in the Current Landscape

#

Gap

Implications

G1

Lack of real‑time PHI‑safe conversational interfaces for OMOP/EHR data.

Investigators rely on manual SQL triage, delaying analysis and stifling exploratory work.

G2

Cloud‑only LLM services create data‑sovereignty, latency, and cost barriers.

Health‑system privacy officers reject cloud APIs for PHI; GPU costs escalate unpredictably.

G3

Generic NLP query tools ignore OMOP vocabularies and clinical ontologies.

Generates incorrect joins, misinterprets clinical codes, undermines trust.

G4

Fragmented privacy safeguards (tokenisation, access control) lack formal guarantees.

Cannot quantify re‑identification risk; auditors block data release.

G5

Little benchmarking of agent architectures (RAG vs SQL‑Agents) in large, normalised clinical warehouses.

Institutions risk committing to sub‑optimal pipelines that cannot scale.

3. How This Proposal Closes the Gaps

Gap Addressed

Solution Element

G1

Natural‑language ChatUtility powered by agentic orchestration; immediate cohort counts, plots, and exportable code snippets.

G2

On‑premise Ollama cluster running LLAMA3‑405B & Deepseek R1; eliminates data egress risk, slashes latency, yields predictable GPU utilisation.

G3

Fine‑tuning on OMOP CDM + LOINC + SNOMED CT; schema‑aware prompt templates; continuous schema‑diff monitoring.

G4

Built‑in differential privacy (ε ≤ 3) for numeric outputs; federated query execution so raw tables remain siloed; NER redaction for free‑text columns; immutable audit logs.

G5

Rigorous head‑to‑head evaluation of Retrieval‑Augmented Generation (RAG) versus LangChain SQL‑Agent pipelines on precision, latency, extensibility, and maintenance burden.

4. Significance

Timely, privacy‑compliant access to comprehensive EHR data is a linchpin for precision medicine, real‑world evidence studies, and rapid clinical decision support.  Yet the gaps identified above (G1–G5) collectively stall discovery and inflate costs: manual query cycles delay hypotheses; cloud LLM prohibitions deny clinicians modern AI tools; schema ignorance breeds mistrust; and incomplete privacy controls hinder data‑sharing collaborations.  AgenticAI directly responds to these pain points with an integrated, on‑premise, privacy‑preserving solution.

Accelerates Translational Science: By collapsing data‑access turnaround from weeks to minutes, AgenticAI empowers investigators to iterate rapidly, increasing the velocity of grant‑funded research and improving time‑to‑publication.

Enhances Patient Safety & Equity: Secure, role‑governed self‑service analytics help reveal care disparities and treatment‑response patterns sooner, enabling evidence‑based interventions for under‑served populations.

Amplifies NIH Investments: The platform leverages and extends community standards (OMOP CDM, OpenDP, LangChain), maximising reuse of NIH‑funded resources such as MIMIC‑III and facilitating multi‑centre synergy across CTSA hubs.

Sets a Compliance Benchmark: Embedding DataLENS policy decisions, differential privacy, and federated execution establishes a replicable blueprint for HIPAA‑aligned AI research, lowering barriers for institutions facing similar regulatory hurdles.

By uniting these advances, AgenticAI transforms gap‑ridden EHR analytics into a scalable, trustworthy, and institutionally compliant ecosystem—exactly the paradigm envisioned by RFA‑OD‑24‑010 to harness emerging AI technologies for biomedical research.

3  State of the Art

NB‑IoT deployments today rely on the SIM/eSIM and 3GPP security layer to prove device identity only at the network‑attach phase. After attachment, application traffic is typically protected by a single‑factor scheme such as:

TLS/DTLS session keys negotiated once per connection.

Pre‑shared API keys or MQTT username/password transmitted every few hours.

Token‑based bootstrapping (e.g., LwM2M Bootstrap) that refreshes credentials daily.

While adequate for many low‑value sensors, these mechanisms expose three gaps for high‑integrity infrastructure monitoring:

No per‑message freshness – replay within a live session is possible if an attacker sniffs traffic near the device.

Weak tamper signalling – most protocols cannot embed a cryptographically verifiable tamper flag inside a routine payload.

Battery trade‑offs – heavyweight DTLS handshakes inflate the energy budget, conflicting with the 10‑year autonomy requirement highlighted in the reference design citeturn1file0.

Academic prototypes of rolling‑code MFA (e.g., TOTP variants) have shown promise, but they assume stable clock drift and are rarely integrated with sub‑256‑byte NB‑IoT payloads. Industry initiatives like GSMA IoT SAFE and OSCORE for CoAP/LwM2M improve key storage and object security, yet still authenticate the session rather than every message.

Title – Targeted AI assistants for Study Teams and Honest Broker processes to facilitate EHR Datasets and Services in support of biomedical research.
Summary Statement:
The use of targeted AI agents to assist in the consultative process between study teams and Honest Brokers can dramatically improve the efficiency and effectiveness of specifying the detailed population and dataset charicteristics required for the development of EHR derived datasets to support research.
Introduction
AI offers opportunity to improve human anchored Honest Broker, and EHR Datasets and Services.  Electronic Health Records and the Clinical data warehouses (CDWs) and Research Data Warehoused (RDWs) have matured into a wealth of clinical and biomedical data resources, and an indispensable research utilities.  That said, the function of verifying appropriate approvals, reefing scientific questions, determination of cohorts, determination of dataset content, and the construction and delivery of datasets is still often a time consuming manual process.  The path from protocol to clean dataset still takes 4–6 weeks on average at leading U.S. academic medical centers — and that is after the first analyst meeting [1 Feinberg School of Medicine]. Multiple reports and institutional town-hall surveys list “terrible turnaround time” and “missing key variables” as the top complaints from investigators who rely on warehouse teams [2 Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai]. While standardization of data models (OMOP, PCORNet), and terminologies/vocabularies allow for automation in some cases, those are very limited.  Effective, targeted AI offers the opportunity to support Data Warehouse Developers and honest brokers, as well as customer facing self service tools to enable what have long been purely manual processes.  
Manual processes, and thus often delays do not stem from one bottleneck but from a series of manual, people-dependent tasks:
•	IRB-to-request discrepancies kick a ticket back to the requester and reset the queue position [3 Boston Medical Center].
•	Researchers describe cohorts in prose; analysts must translate that prose into more specified logic and codes, often over several rounds of email and conversation.
•	Mapping the general ideas to specific concepts or codes from established terminologies/ontologies (ICD-10, SNOMED, RxNorm, LOINC) as well as to a local custom concepts remains a mostly hand-crafted art [5 SNOMED International].
•	Even when the cohort is settled, determining the content of datasets to be delivered is an equally nuanced, and custom process, reliant on human knowledge and interpretations
•	When the desired content of a dataset is established, the writing performant SQL across OMOP, i2b2, or a proprietary RDW structures is a niche skill that few analysts share.
•	Post-delivery, teams file new tickets for every “quick question”, revision, or expansion as the study team initiates the analysis process, thus adding to the queue of request for EDW Developers.
While significant progress has been made in self service, and highly optimized integration and automation, these interactions and bespoke collaborations are the norm.  While a customer may be able to construct a cohort in tools like i2b2, TriNetX, ENACT, etc. and the automation of full structured datasets in OMOP, PcorNet CDM) can be achieved, majority of study teams, or study protocols require the skill and knowledge of the Data Warehouse Developer.  
Timeliness is now a stated quality attribute of EHR data for population health surveillance and precision-medicine studies [7 CDC]. Case studies show that self-service extraction tools and honest-broker pulls can disagree by >100 % on key counts, sowing mistrust and re-work [4 PMC]. At the same time, natural-language–to-SQL research prototypes prove that many of these steps are ripe for automation [8 ACL Anthology].


Motivation
•	Research velocity & cost – Reduced time for the overall process improves the ability for investigators to initiate and support research funding opportunities, and research proposals.  Reduced time and effort on the part of Honest Brokers allows for support of a large number of investigators with limited human resources.  Texas Children’s Hospital cut report-building time from 97 h to <30 h and saved 67 % in labor by automating pieces of the pipeline [9 Health Catalyst].
•	Compliance risk – Assisting the Honest Broker with extraction of PHI approvals and protocol requirements, as well as comparisons between the Protocol details and the requested cohort/data reduces the chance of an impermissible disclosure.
•	Analyst burnout – Guiding study teams through the cohort characteristics, including looking up standard codes, is very time consuming.  Doing this repetitively for many different requests can be a frustrating and intellectually draining activity.  Application of AI agents in this capacity frees developers to work less on routine work, and more on the expansion of tools, services, and value add functions. 
•	Improved Consistency of Cohort Definitions - Consistent, machine assisted terminology mappings and query logic, as well as automatically applied prompts provides for more consistent consideration of various components, and more accurate results (accuracy of

There isn’t an “official” scType rat database the way there is for human and mouse—scType’s built‑in ScTypeDB_full.xlsx ships only human & mouse markers. For rat, you essentially have two paths:

1) Use rcellmarker’s rat atlas
The R package rcellmarker (by Guo & Sun) includes a built‑in rat cell‑type marker database, curated from the literature. You can drive it from Python (via rpy2) or from R directly:

r
Copy
Edit
# in R
library(rcellmarker)
help(auto_cell_label)  # shows you rat support

# run on your Seurat or matrix—no extra DB download needed
res <- auto_cell_label(expr_matrix, species="rat")
That’s the closest thing to a drop‑in scType‑style DB for rat.

2) Lift over scType’s human/mouse DB → rat orthologs
If you really want to leverage scType’s existing marker lists, you can:

Download ScTypeDB_full.xlsx from the scType GitHub.

Extract the mouse (or human) sheets for the tissues you care about.

Map each gene symbol to its rat ortholog via Ensembl or the mygene Python library.

python
Copy
Edit
import mygene
mg = mygene.MyGeneInfo()

# example: map a list of mouse markers to rat
mouse_genes = ["Cd19","Cd27","Ighd",…]
res_mouse = mg.querymany(mouse_genes, scopes="symbol", species="mouse",
                         fields="homologene", as_dataframe=True)
rat_ids  = res_mouse["homologene"]  # may need parsing
rat_genes = mg.getgene(rat_ids.tolist(), fields="symbol", species="rat")
Rebuild your immune_markers dict with those rat symbols, then run your module scoring or SCINA/cellassign pipeline just as you would in scType.

Other rat‐centric resources
CellMarker Database (http://biocc.hrbmu.edu.cn/CellMarker/) has a Rat section full of tissue‑specific markers you can download.

Rat Genome Database (RGD) has curated cell‑type markers under its “Markers” tab (filter by disease/tissue).

ImmPort/ImmGen for rat bulk‐RNA can give you high‑confidence lineage markers to seed your own lists.

TL;DR
Best drop‑in: use rcellmarker’s built‑in rat marker atlas.

DIY: map scType’s human/mouse DB → rat orthologs via Ensembl/mygene, then feed that into your preferred classifier.

CellMarker Database (http://biocc.hrbmu.edu.cn/CellMarker/) has a Rat section full of tissue‑specific markers you can download.

Rat Genome Database (RGD) has curated cell‑type markers under its “Markers” tab (filter by disease/tissue).

ImmPort/ImmGen for rat bulk‐RNA can give you high‑confidence lineage markers to seed your own lists.

2 Context & Challenge

NB‑IoT is poised to connect massive fleets of battery‑powered sensors for utilities and telecom operators, but its security posture still hinges largely on the initial SIM/eSIM attachment. Once the device is on‑air, application traffic often relies on static credentials or long‑lived DTLS sessions—solutions that are ill‑matched to a threat model in which field nodes may sit unattended for years. MAIA‑MFA tackles this problem by providing a fresh, deterministic multifactor code inside every payload, yet several hurdles must be cleared before the concept is production‑ready for ultra‑low‑power deployments:

Message‑level authentication gap. After network attach, most NB‑IoT applications fall back to pre‑shared keys or infrequent handshakes, leaving them vulnerable to replay and tamper once an attacker is near the device.

Tight energy budgets. A ten‑year battery target means radio‑on time must be shaved to seconds per day and any crypto must execute in mere milliseconds on a sub‑MHz MCU.

Cumbersome field provisioning. Today’s installers often key in APNs or credentials by hand. A friction‑free, zero‑touch onboarding workflow is essential if thousands of nodes are to be deployed reliably by non‑specialists.

Heterogeneous hardware landscape. The NB‑IoT ecosystem spans STM32, ESP32, Nordic nRF9160 and emerging RISC‑V chips, each with its own tool‑chain quirks and memory constraints. A portable SDK is required to avoid vendor lock‑in.

Portal‑level visibility. Operators currently see SIM status in MEO Selfcare but lack an application‑layer view that shows which messages were authenticated, rejected or flagged for tamper.

1. From Passive Models to Agentic Systems
Artificial-intelligence agents are rapidly reshaping biomedical and clinical science. Over little more than five years, autonomous systems that observe the world, reason about goals, plan multi-step solutions, and act through the external tools of modern laboratories and hospitals have migrated from proof-of-concept demonstrations into production-grade assistants that design experiments, monitor intensive-care patients, discover drugs, and match volunteers to clinical trials. The agentic turn differs from the previous era of “AI tools.” Classic deep-learning models such as image classifiers or genomic variant callers are powerful, but they are passive: they accept an input, return a prediction, and await the next request. By contrast, an AI-Agent is an application that receives objectives, interprets streaming context, decomposes problems into subtasks, decides which tool to invoke, executes actions, and iteratively refines its own plan—often with only sporadic or high-level human oversight. Instead of a single forward pass, the agent enacts a perception-reason–act loop: it perceives data from the environment, reasons and plans, calls databases, laboratory robots, or clinical APIs, perceives the consequences, and continues until the defined goal has been satisfied or a safety constraint halts execution. This essay surveys the emerging landscape of agents in biomedical and clinical domains, analyses how they manifest core features such as autonomy, proactivity, reasoning and planning, tool utilisation, memory and adaptability, and collaboration, and reflects on technical challenges, ethical considerations and future directions.

2. Why Autonomy Is Essential in Biomedicine
In the biomedical setting, autonomy is not a marketing slogan but a necessity. Wet-lab experiments can last days; clinical datasets can exceed human comprehension; and trial recruitment comprises thousands of inclusion criteria. Agents that wait for line-by-line instructions are impractical. AlphaFold from DeepMind, initially introduced as a predictive model, became an agent the moment it began scheduling its own rotamer searches, terminating sampling when confidence statistics plateaued, and generating actionable insights that feed downstream molecular-docking pipelines. DeepVariant exhibits partial autonomy when it ingests raw FASTQ files, invokes pre-processing tools, decides whether to re-calibrate quality scores, calls variants, and stores results in a genome-analysis warehouse. TrialGPT demonstrates autonomy at the patient interface: given a corpus of trial protocols and a structured patient profile, the agent parses eligibility criteria, reasons about each line, scores fit, generates an explanatory paragraph for the clinician, and returns a ranked list of trials. In hospital operations, Oracle Health’s Clinical AI listens to ambient speech in the consultation room, writes draft SOAP notes, queries formulary APIs for drug–drug interactions, and flags potential conflicts for clinician review. In each instance autonomy saves professional time and scales expertise.

As a specialist in the field related to the content of the research papers, your task is to create an extensive and detailed summary that synthesizes information across all documents. The goal is to provide the audience with a deep understanding of the research, including detailed and concrete information such as substance names, herb names, target diseases, symptoms, methodologies, and key findings. Use clear and precise language to convey complex ideas effectively.

1. Comprehensive Literature Review: Develop a detailed literature review that synthesizes information from all papers, providing a holistic view of the research landscape. Include references to the file names as typically done in literature reviews. Organize the information into several paragraphs, summarizing the key findings, methodologies, theoretical frameworks, results, and discussions from the research papers. Highlight the essence of the research, capturing both the breadth and depth of the studies.

2. Results and Benefits: Elaborate on the specific results obtained in the research papers and the tangible benefits derived from these results. Provide detailed descriptions and analyses, organizing the information into several paragraphs for each result and benefit. Highlight any novel findings, significant improvements, or advantages over existing solutions. Include concrete data, statistical significance, and specific examples where available.

3. Potential Applications: Discuss the potential applications of the research findings in various fields or industries. Provide detailed scenarios and use cases, explaining how the research can be translated into practical solutions. Organize the information into several paragraphs for each potential application, ensuring a thorough exploration of each aspect.

4. Concerns: Identify and discuss any concerns, limitations, or challenges associated with the research findings. Provide a balanced view by exploring potential drawbacks, risks, or areas where further investigation is needed. Organize the information into several paragraphs for each concern, ensuring a comprehensive and critical analysis.

5. Suggested Next Steps (as a Pharmaceutical Institute): Based on the research findings, propose concrete and actionable next steps that a pharmaceutical institute could take to further develop and implement the research. These steps should be specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound (SMART). Consider potential research directions, clinical trials, drug development strategies, and collaborations that could advance the field. Organize the information into several paragraphs, providing a clear roadmap for future endeavors.

Ensure that the summary is exhaustive and leaves no critical information unaddressed. Aim for clarity and depth, making the content accessible to both experts and informed readers. Each section should be detailed and comprehensive, providing a balanced view of the research.

 Experiment 1-3: The influence of a How-To-Guide on the detection of:
i) Paired real and AI-generated images,
ii) Low-resolution (CCTV) real and AI-generated images, and
iii) Real and AI-generated images depicting diverse gender-occupation pairings.

Hypothesis: Exposure to the how-to-guide will significantly improve participants' ability to distinguish between real and AI-generated images, as measured by accuracy.


Method:


Participants: Randomly assign participants to two groups (group A and group B).
Stimuli 1: A dataset of 100 images (50 real, 50 AI-generated) balanced across various dimensions (pose complexity, etc.)
Stimuli 2: A dataset of 100 images (50 real, 50 AI-generated), with each group (A and B) containing an equal mix of 25 high-resolution and 25 low-resolution images.
Stimuli 3: A dataset of 100 images (50 real, 50 AI-generated), with each group (A and B) containing images depicting diverse gender-occupation pairings.

Procedure:
Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions:
Group A then Group B: Participants in this condition will first view and classify the 50 images in Group A, then watch a 5-minute video on the how-to-guide, and finally view and classify the 50 images in Group B.


Group B then Group A: Participants in this condition will follow the reverse order, starting with Group B, then watching the video, and concluding with Group A.
Each group (A and B) contains 50 images, with randomized presentation order within each group.

Experiment 4-6: The Impact of LLM-Assisted Intervention on the detection of:
i) Paired real and AI-generated images,
ii) Low-resolution (CCTV) real and AI-generated images, and
iii) Real and AI-generated images depicting diverse gender-occupation pairings.

Hypothesis: An LLM-assisted intervention will enhance participants' ability to distinguish between real and AI-generated images.
Method:


Participants: Randomly assign participants to two groups (group A and group B).
Stimuli 1: A dataset of 100 images (50 real, 50 AI-generated) balanced across various dimensions (pose complexity, etc.)
Stimuli 2: A dataset of 100 images (50 real, 50 AI-generated), with each group (A and B) containing an equal mix of 25 high-resolution and 25 low-resolution images.
Stimuli 3: A dataset of 100 images (50 real, 50 AI-generated), with each group (A and B) containing images depicting diverse gender-occupation pairings.

Procedure:

Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions:
Participants in this condition will first view and classify 50 images from Group A. In the second part of the experiment, they will receive just-in-time assistance from the LLM and classify the 50 images in Group B.


Participants in this condition will begin with Group B images, classifying them without assistance. In the second part, they will view and classify Group A images with just-in-time assistance provided by the LLM.
Each group (A and B) contains 50 images, with randomized presentation order within each group.

Experiment 7-9: The Impact of Wizard-of-Oz LLM-Assisted intervention on the detection of:
i) Paired real and AI-generated images,
ii) Low-resolution (CCTV) real and AI-generated images, and
iii) Real and AI-generated images depicting diverse gender-occupation pairings.

Hypothesis: A Wizard-of-Oz LLM-assisted intervention, simulating expert-level advice or the performance of a highly accurate LLM, will enhance participants' ability to distinguish between real and AI-generated images.
Method:


Participants: Randomly assign participants to two groups (group A and group B).
Stimuli 1: A dataset of 100 images (50 real, 50 AI-generated) balanced across various dimensions (pose complexity, etc.)
Stimuli 2: A dataset of 100 images (50 real, 50 AI-generated), with each group (A and B) containing an equal mix of 25 high-resolution and 25 low-resolution images.
Stimuli 3: A dataset of 100 images (50 real, 50 AI-generated), with each group (A and B) containing images depicting diverse gender-occupation pairings.

Procedure:
Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions:
Participants in this condition will first view and classify 50 images from Group A without assistance. In the second part of the experiment, they will classify the 50 images in Group B with just-in-time assistance from the Wizard-of-Oz LLM, simulating expert-level guidance or a highly accurate LLM.

Participants in this condition will start by classifying the 50 images from Group B without assistance. In the second part, they will classify the 50 images in Group A with just-in-time assistance provided by the Wizard-of-Oz LLM.

Each group (A and B) contains 50 images, with randomized presentation order within each group. The Wizard-of-Oz LLM is designed to mimic the quality of expert advice, serving as a benchmark for assessing the potential of LLMs to improve discernment in detecting real vs. AI-generated images.
Experiment 10: The Role of display time on detection of AI-generated and real images
Hypothesis: Participants' ability to distinguish between real and AI-generated images will vary significantly under different display times.
Method:
Participants: Randomly select participants for this condition.
Stimuli: Use the same image dataset from Experiment 1.
Procedure: Participants will begin the experiment by viewing and classifying the first five images with unlimited time to familiarize themselves with the task. After these initial five images, each subsequent image will be displayed under one of six different time constraints (1s, 5s, 10s, 20s, 32s, and unlimited). The time constraints will be randomly assigned across the remaining 95 images. There are no interventions or assistance provided in this experiment; the focus is solely on the influence of time constraints on classification accuracy.

Chlorophyll-a (Chl-a) is the primary green pigment present in the chloroplasts of all phytoplankton groups, including algae and cyanobacteria. Its fundamental role in photosynthesis is to absorb sunlight, particularly in the blue and red wavelengths, and convert this solar energy into chemical energy. This process enables phytoplankton to produce organic compounds (like glucose) from carbon dioxide and water, releasing oxygen as a byproduct.
phytoplankton to produce organic compounds (like glucose) from carbon dioxide and water, releasing oxygen as a byproduct
advanteges and disadvanteges of Chl-a as  a water quality index in lakes

Elevated levels of Chl-a typically indicate eutrophic conditions, which result from nutrient enrichment, particularly from nitrogen and phosphorus, and are often caused by agricultural runoff, wastewater discharge, and urban sources. Such nutrient loading can trigger excessive phytoplankton growth, leading to reduced water clarity, oxygen depletion (especially in bottom waters due to decomposition), and the formation of harmful algal blooms (HABs), including toxin-producing cyanobacteria. These changes can impair aquatic life, affect recreational use, and degrade drinking water quality (Anderson, 2002).

low Chl-a concentrations are characteristic of oligotrophic lakes, which are generally nutrient-poor, have high water clarity, and are less susceptible to algal blooms. Therefore, Chl-a serves not only as a robust indicator of phytoplankton dynamics but also as an early warning metric for water quality deterioration, making it a valuable tool in lake monitoring and management strategies.

Precipitation can cool the lake surface, altering thermal stratification.

In stratified lakes, this might enhance mixing, redistributing nutrients and temporarily increasing Chl-a.

Alternatively, cold rainfall can strengthen stratification if the surface cools more than the subsurface, potentially limiting nutrient exchange and decreasing Chl-a

Rainfall over the lake surface can play a key role in altering the water column structure and influencing biological activity, which impacts chlorophyll-a concentration. When precipitation occurs, the cooler rainwater lowers the lake surface temperature, weakening the thermal stratification and deepening the mixing layer. This vertical mixing can redistribute nutrients already present within the lake, especially from bottom layers into surface waters. Although the immediate effect of rainfall can increase turbidity and reduce light penetration, temporarily limiting algal photosynthesis, the subsequent stabilization of the water column and the availability of nutrients can stimulate phytoplankton growth. Therefore, rainfall directly over the lake surface, independent of river inflows, can contribute to changes in chlorophyll-a concentration by reshaping the thermal structure and internal nutrient cycling.

Rainfall over the lake surface can play a key role in altering the water column structure and influencing biological activity, which impacts chlorophyll-a concentration. When precipitation occurs, the cooler rainwater can lower the lake surface temperature, weakening the thermal stratification and deepening the mixing layer (Rooney, 2018; Liu, 2020). This vertical mixing can redistribute nutrients already present within the lake, especially from bottom layers into surface waters. Although the immediate effect of rainfall can increase turbidity and reduce light penetration, temporarily limiting algal photosynthesis, the subsequent stabilization of the water column and the availability of nutrients can stimulate phytoplankton growth. Therefore, rainfall directly over the lake surface, independent of river inflows, can contribute to changes in Chl-a concentration by reshaping the thermal structure and internal nutrient cycling (Liu, 2020).

Lake surface water temperature (LSWT) was chosen as a key variable to study Chl-a because it plays a central role in how lakes function (Kraemer et al., 2015, Woolway et al., 2020). LSWT directly influences the formation and mixing of thermal layers within a lake. As the surface warms, the upper layer of water, known as the epilimnion, becomes less dense than the colder, deeper water beneath it, resulting in a separation of layers. This process, called thermal stratification, leads to a more stable epilimnion that resists mixing with the hypolimnion below. The stability of this stratification increases with larger temperature differences, making it more difficult for wind or other forces to mix the water column. Reduced vertical mixing limits the upward transport of nutrients from deeper waters, while allowing more sunlight to reach the surface layer. These conditions particularly favor the growth of surface-dwelling phytoplankton such as cyanobacteria, which thrive in warm, stable, and well-lit environments (Woolway et al., 2020).

The Spearman correlation was selected because it is a non-parametric method that assesses monotonic relationships without requiring normally distributed data or linearity assumptions—characteristics that make it suitable for ecological and hydrological data, which often exhibit skewness and non-linear patterns (Noether, 1981; Bishara & Hittner, 2012). Additionally, Spearman's method is less influenced by outliers and is appropriate for ranked or ordinal measurements, making it a reliable choice for linking streamflow variability with biogeochemical responses.

To further illustrate the inconsistent nature of chlorophyll-a (Chl-a) responses in river-connected lakes to extreme upstream streamflow events, it is instructive to examine the effects of upstream flood events, which serve as key drivers of high streamflow discharge. On one hand, floods can enhance nutrient transport, particularly phosphorus and nitrogen, from upstream catchments. This process can stimulate phytoplankton growth and elevate Chl-a concentrations in downstream lakes. On the other hand, flood-induced increases in turbidity and inflow velocity can disrupt lake thermal structure and reduce light penetration, ultimately suppressing algal productivity

Biochar in Indian Paddy Fields: A Systematic Review of Greenhouse Gas Mitigation Mechanisms, Socioeconomic Barriers, and Policy Pathways

create a well written literature review on the topic Biochar in Indian Paddy Fields: A Systematic Review of Greenhouse Gas Mitigation Mechanisms, Socioeconomic Barriers, and Policy Pathways

**1. Title & Abstract**  
- **Title**: *"Biochar in Indian Paddy Fields: A Systematic Review of Greenhouse Gas Mitigation Mechanisms, Socioeconomic Barriers, and Policy Pathways"*  
- **Abstract**:  
  - Highlight the dual challenge of rice production (food security vs. GHG emissions).  
  - Emphasize biochar’s **triple role**: GHG reduction, soil health improvement, and waste valorization.  
  - Mention **novelty**: Integration of geospatial data, farmer adoption frameworks, and circular bioeconomy principles.  

---

### **2. Introduction**  
#### **2.1 The GHG Crisis in Indian Agriculture**  
  - Quantify India’s CH₄ and N₂O emissions from rice paddies (cite FAO/GOI reports).  
  - Link to climate goals (NDC targets under the Paris Agreement).  

#### **2.2 Biochar: Beyond Carbon Sequestration**  
  - Introduce biochar as a **circular economy tool** (converting crop residues into a resource).  
  - Contrast with traditional mitigation strategies (e.g., intermittent flooding, urea deep placement).  

#### **2.3 Novelty of This Review**  
  - **Unique angle**: Bridging biophysical mechanisms, socioeconomic constraints, and scalable policy solutions.  
  - **Gaps addressed**:  
    - Regional variability in biochar efficacy across India’s agroclimatic zones.  
    - Behavioral barriers to farmer adoption.  

---

### **3. Methodology**  
#### **3.1 Hybrid Review Approach**  
  - Combine **systematic review** (PRISMA guidelines) with **narrative synthesis** for interdisciplinary insights.  
  - **Databases**: Scopus, Web of Science, AGRIS, and **regional databases** (e.g., Krishikosh, Indian Agricultural Research Institute).  

#### **3.2 Inclusion Criteria**  
  - **Geographic focus**: India + comparable tropical regions (Bangladesh, Vietnam).  
  - **Study types**: Field experiments, life-cycle assessments (LCAs), and socioeconomic surveys.  

#### **3.3 Thematic Coding Framework**  
  - Code studies into:  
    1. **Biophysical mechanisms** (CH₄/N₂O suppression).  
    2. **Socioeconomic drivers** (cost-benefit analyses, farmer perceptions).  
    3. **Policy interventions** (subsidies, carbon markets).  

---

### **4. Biochar Production and Application: An Indian Context**  
#### **4.1 Feedstock Valorization**  
  - Map India’s **agricultural waste hotspots** (e.g., rice husk in Punjab, sugarcane bagasse in Maharashtra).  
  - Compare traditional kilns vs. modern pyrolysis: **energy efficiency** and **scalability**.  

#### **4.2 Biochar-Soil Dynamics in Flooded Systems**  
  - **Novel mechanistic focus**:  
    - Role of **biochar-induced redox fluctuations** on methanogen communities.  
    - **Electron shuttle theory**: Biochar as a mediator in soil electron transfer (reducing N₂O emissions).  

---

### **5. GHG Mitigation Mechanisms: Evidence from Indian Case Studies**  
#### **5.1 Methane (CH₄) Suppression**  
  - **Key findings**:  
    - Biochar increases soil porosity, enhancing **aerobic methane oxidation** (cite Tamil Nadu trials).  
    - Alkaline biochar (pH >9) inhibits methanogens (e.g., coconut shell biochar in Kerala).  

#### **5.2 Nitrous Oxide (N₂O) Reduction**  
  - **Mechanisms**:  
    - Biochar adsorbs NH₄⁺, reducing substrate for nitrification/denitrification.  
    - **Microbial interplay**: Biochar promotes nosZ gene abundance (N₂O → N₂).  

#### **5.3 Carbon Sequestration Potential**  
  - **Long-term stability**: Biochar’s aromatic structure resists decomposition (half-life >100 years).  
  - **Synergy with Indian soils**: High clay content in Gangetic soils enhances biochar retention.  

---

### **6. Beyond GHG Mitigation: Co-Benefits for Indian Agriculture**  
#### **6.1 Soil Health Enhancement**  
  - **Nutrient retention**: Biochar’s CEC (cation exchange capacity) reduces fertilizer leaching.  
  - **pH buffering**: Remediation of acidic soils in Northeast India.  

#### **6.2 Climate Resilience**  
  - **Drought mitigation**: Biochar’s water-holding capacity in water-stressed regions (e.g., Maharashtra).  
  - **Yield stability**: Meta-analysis of 15 Indian studies showing 10–15% yield increase.  

---

### **7. Socioeconomic Barriers to Adoption**  
#### **7.1 Cost-Benefit Analysis**  
  - **Production costs**: ₹2,000–5,000/ton for small-scale pyrolysis.  
  - **Farmer ROI**: Break-even period (3–5 years) vs. short-term crop cycles.  

#### **7.2 Behavioral Challenges**  
  - **Case study**: Odisha farmers reluctant to adopt due to **lack of awareness** and **labor constraints**.  
  - **Gender dynamics**: Women’s role in residue management vs. male-dominated decision-making.  

#### **7.3 Policy Gaps**  
  - Critique of India’s **National Mission on Sustainable Agriculture (NMSA)**: No explicit biochar incentives.  
  - Lessons from **Vietnam’s biochar subsidies** and **Sri Lanka’s carbon credit programs**.  

---

### **8. A Scalable Roadmap for India**  
#### **8.1 Technological Innovations**  
  - **Mobile pyrolysis units**: Decentralized, low-cost production for smallholders.  
  - **Biochar-blended fertilizers**: Partnerships with companies like IFFCO.  

#### **8.2 Policy Interventions**  
  - **Carbon farming credits**: Integrate biochar into India’s **PAT (Perform, Achieve, Trade)** scheme.  
  - **Awareness campaigns**: Leverage KVKs (Krishi Vigyan Kendras) for farmer training.  

#### **8.3 Circular Bioeconomy Framework**  
  - **Waste-to-wealth model**: Link biochar production to **Swachh Bharat Mission** (crop residue management).  
  - **Public-private partnerships**: Role of startups like *Farm2Energy* in scaling adoption.  

---

### **9. Future Research Directions**  
#### **9.1 Priority Areas**  
  - **Biochar-microbe interactions**: Metagenomic studies on methanotrophs in Indian soils.  
  - **Nano-biochar composites**: Enhanced nutrient delivery systems.  

#### **9.2 Policy-Oriented Research**  
  - **Farmer willingness-to-pay surveys** across states.  
  - **Life-cycle assessments (LCAs)** comparing biochar to other mitigation strategies.  

---

### **10. Conclusion**  
- **Key takeaway**: Biochar is a **win-win strategy** for GHG mitigation and sustainable agriculture, but requires **tailored approaches** for India’s diversity.  
- **Call to action**: Urge interdisciplinary collaboration between agronomists, economists, and policymakers.

**9.2 Policy-Oriented Research**  
  - **Farmer willingness-to-pay surveys** across states.  
  - **Life-cycle assessments (LCAs)** comparing biochar to other mitigation strategies.

What is right based and equity theory

Rights-Based and Equity Theories

From a rights-based perspective, social assistance is not merely a tool for economic development but a legal and moral obligation of the state. This perspective is grounded in international frameworks such as the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, which recognize the right to health and social security.

Organizations such as the ILO and WHO advocate for universal health coverage (UHC) through comprehensive social protection, arguing that equitable access to healthcare should not depend on income (Yokobori et al., 2023). In this context, social assistance programs are essential components of health equity and social justice, particularly for marginalized groups like children, women, and the elderly.

Child Nutrition and Health Service Utilization – Key Definitions and Indicators

SECTION 3: Existing Literature on the Long-Term Impact of Social Assistance on Health Outcomes

3.1 Introduction

This section reviews the empirical literature on the relationship between social assistance programs and health outcomes in Sub-Saharan Africa, with particular attention to child nutrition and health service utilization. While there is growing evidence supporting the short-term benefits of cash transfer programs, studies focusing on their long-term health impacts remain limited, often with mixed results. This review highlights key findings, gaps, and methodological challenges within the existing body of research.


---

3.2 Evidence of Short-Term Health Benefits

A substantial number of studies report that social assistance programs—particularly cash transfers—lead to immediate improvements in health behaviors and service uptake. For instance, programs such as South Africa’s Child Support Grant (CSG) have been linked to higher rates of immunization, improved clinic attendance, and reductions in food insecurity. Similar effects have been observed in Ghana’s LEAP 1000, which targets pregnant women and mothers of young children, contributing to enhanced dietary diversity and antenatal care use.

In Zambia and Malawi, unconditional cash transfer schemes have shown significant reductions in child morbidity and improvements in household food security and stress reduction among caregivers. These results support the view that when financial constraints are eased, families are more likely to invest in preventive healthcare and improved nutrition.


---

3.3 Mixed Findings on Long-Term Outcomes

Despite these encouraging results, the long-term health effects of social assistance programs remain less conclusive. Some studies have found that positive impacts on child nutrition—such as reduced stunting or improved growth indicators—either diminish over time or fail to materialize in the absence of complementary interventions. For example, increases in food consumption do not always translate into measurable anthropometric improvements, particularly in contexts with persistent environmental or healthcare access challenges.

Moreover, while early access to benefits has been associated with better outcomes—such as higher birth weight and developmental gains—the sustainability of these effects is often unclear. Many evaluations report on program impact within 12 to 24 months, leaving questions about durability unanswered.


---

3.4 Importance of Program Design

Recent literature emphasizes that program characteristics play a critical role in shaping outcomes. Factors such as conditionality, targeting strategies, payment frequency, and integration with health services can significantly influence effectiveness. Programs that combine cash with other forms of support—often called "cash-plus" models—have shown greater success in sustaining health improvements, particularly in early childhood development and maternal well-being.

For example, interventions that include nutrition counseling, parenting support, or health education alongside cash transfers have demonstrated more consistent impacts on child growth and cognitive outcomes than cash alone. This suggests that program design is not just an administrative detail but a determinant of impact.


---

3.5 Methodological Gaps and Limitations

A major limitation in the literature is the scarcity of longitudinal studies capable of capturing delayed or sustained effects. Most available evidence relies on cross-sectional or short-term impact evaluations. Additionally, few studies conduct comparative analysis across multiple countries, limiting generalizability and understanding of contextual influences.

Another overlooked area is the impact of social assistance on mental health and psychosocial outcomes, particularly for caregivers. Although caregiver well-being is recognized as crucial for child health, it is rarely incorporated into program assessments or considered in health impact models.


---

3.6 Summary

Overall, the literature indicates that social assistance programs hold promise for improving health outcomes in the short term, particularly when paired with complementary services. However, the evidence on long-term impacts is mixed and often inconclusive. Program design features appear to play a decisive role in determining success, yet remain underexplored in many studies. These gaps underscore the need for more nuanced, longitudinal, and cross-country analyses—an objective that this study seeks to address in the subsequent empirical chapters.

. Human Capital Theory (Becker, 1964)

Relevance:
Human Capital Theory posits that investments in health and education enhance individual productivity and long-term economic outcomes. Cash transfer programs can be viewed as investments in human capital, particularly when they improve child nutrition, maternal health, and access to preventive healthcare. By enhancing early childhood development through improved nutrition and health services, social assistance fosters long-term gains in physical and cognitive capacity, which are essential for future labor productivity.

Application to Study:
Programs like South Africa’s CSG and Ghana’s LEAP 1000 increase access to food and healthcare, thus improving early childhood health—a critical period for human capital formation.

Key social assistance program characteristics (conditionality) in sub Saharan Africa

3.1 Introduction

This section identifies and discusses key program design features of social assistance interventions and outlines the theoretical pathways through which these features can influence health outcomes. The aim is to establish how differences in program structure—such as conditionality, benefit adequacy, and targeting—can either enhance or limit the effectiveness of social assistance in addressing child nutrition and increasing health service utilization. These design features are central to understanding why similar programs may yield varying outcomes across countries and contexts.(Sub Sahara Africa)

Conditionality

Conditionality refers to whether a program requires beneficiaries to meet specific criteria—such as attending health clinics or enrolling children in school—as a condition for receiving benefits. Conditional cash transfer (CCT) programs are designed to incentivize positive behaviors, especially in health and education. In contrast, unconditional transfers rely on household discretion and are often preferred in settings where access to services is limited or conditional monitoring is costly.(Sub Sahara Africa)

Transfer Size

The size or value of the cash transfer is a critical determinant of its effectiveness. Larger or more adequate transfers are more likely to generate meaningful improvements in consumption, nutrition, and access to services. When transfers are too small relative to household needs or the cost of living, their potential health impact is significantly diminished.(sub Sahara Africa with statistics if necessary )

Payment Frequency

Regularity and predictability of payments—typically monthly or quarterly—affect household planning, consumption stability, and ability to engage consistently with health services. Irregular disbursement can undermine trust in the program and limit its effectiveness in addressing ongoing health needs.(Sub Sahara Africa with statistics)

An Overview of the State of Iran's Ecosystem Diversity
Iran's territory, with an area of ​​1,648,000 square kilometers, consists of humid forests in the plains and coastal areas of the Caspian Sea, deciduous broadleaf forests on the northern slopes of the Alborz Mountains, sparse forests or dry woodlands in the Zagros Mountains and northern Khorasan, as well as mangrove forests and semi-desert shrubs in the Persian Gulf regions, dense and sparse forest areas of this land.
Iran's deserts are divided into two main groups: coastal deserts and inland deserts.

The concept of megadiverse countries, or countries with very high biodiversity, was first introduced by the famous primatologist Russell Mittermeier. The term quickly became a favorite concept among scientists and politicians and was recognized as the biological wealth of the people of the planet. 17 countries that contain more than 70 percent of the Earth’s biodiversity have become known as key countries for the conservation of global biodiversity. According to this classification, a small number of countries have a large share of biodiversity. In 2002, ministers or environmental officials and representatives from Bolivia, Brazil, China, Colombia, Costa Rica, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Ecuador, India, Indonesia, Kenya, Madagascar, Malaysia, Mexico, Peru, the Philippines, South Africa and Venezuela met in Mexico City. They then introduced a group of like-minded countries with very high biodiversity (megadiverse). The aim of this work was to foster consensus and cooperation on interests and priorities related to the conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity. Iran is also the cradle of genetic diversity of many plant and animal species in the world and is classified in the group of like-minded countries with very high biodiversity.

Biodiversity hotspots are biogeographic regions with the highest density of native species and the greatest habitat destruction.

Protected Areas
Protected areas are large areas of high conservation value that are selected for the purpose of preserving and restoring plant and animal habitats. These areas are also considered suitable environments for implementing educational programs, tourism, and environmental research, which are permitted according to the capabilities of each area and based on a comprehensive area management plan (Dudley, 2008).

Protected areas serve multiple purposes beyond biodiversity conservation. They are intended to meet objectives including scientific research, education, wilderness protection, preservation of species and genetic diversity, maintenance of environmental services, protection of specific natural and cultural features, tourism and recreation, sustainable use of resources, and maintenance of cultural and traditional attributes

In Iran, a study of the distribution of protected areas shows that these areas encompass almost all of the country's biodiversity. Although the importance of these areas in maintaining biological populations and maintaining habitat integrity and species diversity has been proven, there is little chance that these areas can cover the dynamics of different ecosystems in the long term.

In Iran, all four areas (national park, national natural monument, wildlife sanctuary, and protected area) were introduced after the establishment of the Hunting Organization. The Iranian Hunting Center, which was established as an independent organization based on the Hunting Law to preserve wild animals and implement hunting regulations, became the Hunting and Fishing Supervision Organization in 1967.

History and Laws of Protected Areas in Iran
In 1956, the first conservation law was passed with the establishment of a hunting center in Iran, providing the foundation for a targeted program for wildlife conservation.

History and Laws of Protected Areas:
In Iran, all four areas (national park, national natural monument, wildlife sanctuary, and protected area) were introduced after the establishment of the Hunting and Fishing Organization. The Iranian Hunting Center, which was established as an independent organization based on the Hunting Law to preserve the wild animals and implement hunting regulations, was transformed into the Hunting and Fishing Supervision Organization in 1967 (Majnounian, 2002). In Iran, as in many countries around the world, parts of natural environments have long been designated as exclusive hunting grounds by the nobility or the royal family and people were prevented from entering them. Khojir and Sorkhehesar around Tehran or Qomishlo around Isfahan are among these areas. However, the history of the legal introduction of the first protected area in Iran dates back to 1336 AH (corresponding to 1957 AD), one year after the approval of the Hunting and Fishing Law and the establishment of the Iranian Hunting Center. In this year, Golestan Forest was declared as the first protected area in Iran, and then in 1967, the same area was registered as the first national park in Iran. In 1964, the Iranian Hunting Center introduced the Kavir Protected Area and in 1965, the Marakan Protected Area, both of which are valuable habitats for some of Iran's huntable species, as protected areas. In 1967, more areas were declared as protected areas (Majnounian, 2002).
